text:
• The best hotels on London's South Bank 
T he latest penthouse space is an extension of the hotel’s overall focus on a more art- and design-conscious look which can be traced from the lobby to its executive lounge, where guests are met by elegant wingback chairs and black marble reception desks overlooked by original design ceiling lights with a celestial feel. Personal home-like touches include shelves scattered with cookery and art books, and decorative glass bottles 
T he suite’s most eye-catching feature – a portrait of a woman overlaid with a hypnotic black-and-white swirling pattern (an image from Russian photographer Alexander Khokhlov’s Weird Beauty series) – forms a secret sliding wall (behind which is the lounge's television) and a backdrop for other edgy touches including metal-studded furnishings, unusually shaped lamps and bold light fixtures. The all-marble bathroom includes a long corridor-like shower large enough for two 
• The best hotels near Oxford Circus 
V elvet sofas, floral patterned pillows, as well as marble and glass table tops balance out the edges with a classic and sophisticated feel. 
T he suite's art-inspired theme pays homage to the nearby Tate Modern and continues in the spacious bedroom with an easel-shaped television stand, while two sliding doors above the head of the bed form an abstract painting when shut, showcased by display lights. The doors open onto a giant all-marble bathroom with a long corridor-like shower large enough for two and an intimate bathtub. The hotel’s overall focus on a more art- and design-conscious look can be traced from the lobby 
• The best London hotels with river views 
T he lofty penthouse is bathed in natural light, with half of it surrounded by floor-to-ceiling windows, including in the bedroom, while a mini-staircase leads to a spacious outdoor terrace, surrounded by a strip of green “meadow” which houses the hotel's own rooftop beehives in the summer. 
S tepping out onto the deck, the views are mostly of office buildings (with the tip of the Shard peeking out in the distance), and admittedly not especially inspiring. But the cosy space offers a quiet moment away from the rush of the city and feels ideal for a small gathering or a romantic nightcap for two under warm fleece blankets, which can be found in the living room closet. The spacious outdoor terrace is surrounded by a green “meadow” which houses the hotel's own rooftop beehives in the summer 
• The best design hotels in London 
W ith homely touches, from shelves scattered with modern art sculptures, cookery and art books, and decorative glass bottles to a kitchenette with a nifty Nespresso milk frother for cappuccino- and latte-making enthusiasts, the suite feels like an apartment for a cultured couple with a sophisticated 'hipster' edge. Could this be Hilton's new face of the future? Watch this space.
